geninfo.para: Due to certain conditions, which can only be met prior to or during initial seat belt installation, self-retracting seat belt assemblies can experience what is known as "Reverse Lock-up". When it occurs, the belt cannot be pulled out of the retractor and appears to be "locked". This condition is either caused by excessive webbing spooled into the retractor before it is installed into the vehicle or the belt retractor not being in the vertical position. The seat belts in International Trucks are a part of a critical occupant protection system. The individual components of these safety belt systems are carefully designed, factory calibrated and tested to meet exacting Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards. Follow the procedures to assure continued compliance.

svcproc.title: Service Procedure

warning.para: Do not attempt to repair a seat belt component. This action could expose the truck occupants to serious injury or death in the event of a significant vehicle crash.

svcproc.para: To unlock an installed seat belt assembly that exhibits "Reverse Lock-up" characteristics, perform the following steps:

step1.para: If the retractor becomes locked up after installation in the vehicle, verify that the retractor is mounted in the 90 degree position as shown in Figure 1 and Figure 2.
Firmly grasp the webbing close to the retractor as shown in Figure 2 .
Pull the webbing with enough force to tighten the webbing on the spool.
Release the webbing. This should allow ½" of webbing to feed back into the retractor storage spool; the retractor should unlock.

note.para: If the above steps do not correct the seat belt function or if the unit continues to lockup without a load, REPLACE THE ENTIRE SEAT BELT ASSEMBLY!

svcproc.para: To unlock an uninstalled seat belt assembly that exhibits "Reverse Lock-up" characteristics, perform the following steps:

item.para: Clamp the retractor assembly in a vice at a 90 degree orientation as shown in Figure 3.
Pull on the webbing with enough force to tighten the webbing on the spool.
Release the webbing. This should allow ½" of webbing to feed back into the retractor storage spool; the retractor should unlock.

After the retractor is unlocked, pull the webbing out of the retractor, allow only 12-15" to retract, and lock the Komfort Latch on the webbing as shown in Figure 4. This will prevent the webbing from fully retracting onto the spool and permitting the system to lock-up.

note.para: Some applications do not include a Komfort Latch. These units usually include a cardboard stop to prevent excessive webbing from spooling back onto the retractor. This cardboard stop should only be removed after the vehicle installation is complete.
